dt: {bc}to move back and forth in or as if in a cradle

dt.t: She gently {wi}rocked{/wi} the baby to sleep.

dt: {bc}to cause to sway back and forth

dt.t: a boat {wi}rocked{/wi} by the waves
An earthquake {wi}rocked{/wi} the town.

dt: {bc}to daze with or as if with a vigorous blow

dt.t: A hard right {wi}rocked{/wi} the contender.
The scandal {wi}rocked{/wi} the community.

dt: {bc}to rouse to excitement (as by performing rock music)

dt.t: The band {wi}rocked{/wi} the crowd.

dt: {bc}to wear, display, or feature (something striking, distinctive, or attractive)

dt.t: Carly Patterson is {wi}rocking{/wi} a tight yellow T-shirt with jeans and high wooden sandals, belting her lyrics into a microphone.
In the picture he's {wi}rocking{/wi} a beard, a pair of shades and a striped t-shirt.

dt: {bc}to become moved backward and forward under often violent impact

dt.t: The tower {wi}rocked{/wi} under the impact of the hurricane.
{wi}rocked{/wi} on the balls of his feet

dt: {bc}to move forward at a steady pace
{bc}to move forward at a high speed

dt.t: the train {wi}rocked{/wi} through the countryside

dt: {bc}to sing, dance to, or play rock music

dt.t: The band was {wi}rocking{/wi} all night long.

dt: {bc}to be extremely enjoyable, pleasing, or effective

dt.t: her new car {wi}rocks{/wi}

dt: {bc}to do something that disturbs the equilibrium of a situation

pt: {sc}shake{/sc} {sc}agitate{/sc} {sc}rock{/sc} {sc}convulse{/sc} mean to move up and down or to and fro with some violence. {sc}shake{/sc} often carries a further implication of a particular purpose.
{sc}agitate{/sc} suggests a violent and prolonged tossing or stirring.
{sc}rock{/sc} suggests a swinging or swaying motion resulting from violent impact or upheaval.

pt.t: the whole city was {it}rocked{/it} by the explosion

pt: {sc}convulse{/sc} suggests a violent pulling or wrenching as of a body in a paroxysm.

et: Middle English {it}rokken{/it}, from Old English {it}roccian{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}rucken{/it} to cause to move
shortdef: to move back and forth in or as if in a cradle
to cause to sway back and forth

dt: {bc}popular music usually played on electronically amplified instruments and characterized by a persistent heavily accented beat, repetition of simple phrases, and often country, folk, and blues elements

shortdef: popular music usually played on electronically amplified instruments and characterized by a persistent heavily accented beat, repetition of simple phrases, and often country, folk, and blues elements

stems: between a rock and a hard place
between the rock and the hard place

dt: {bc}a large mass of stone forming a cliff, promontory, or peak

dt.t: The superintendent describes [Michael] Doran as a {wi}rock{/wi} on which the success of the school is and will continue to be built.
a {wi}rock{/wi} of independent thought … in an ocean of parochialism
By the late 1930's, the university, so near the {wi}rocks{/wi} in preceding years, had become one of the best-rounded educational institutions in the country.

dt: {bc}a flavored stick candy with color running through
{bc}a small crystallized mass of crack cocaine

dt.t: Who's going to fight through screens or risk lumps and lacerations lunging into the stands after the {wi}rock{/wi}?

dros.drp: between a rock and a hard place

vrs.va: between the rock and the hard place

dt: {bc}in a difficult or uncomfortable position with no attractive way out
{bc}in or into a state of destruction or wreckage

dt.t: their marriage is {it}on the rocks{/it}
bourbon {it}on the rocks{/it}

et: Middle English {it}rokke{/it}, from Old French dialect (Norman & Picard) {it}roke{/it}, from Vulgar Latin {it}*rocca{/it}
shortdef: a large mass of stone forming a cliff, promontory, or peak
a concreted mass of stony material; also : broken pieces of such masses
consolidated or unconsolidated solid mineral matter; also : a particular mass of it

et: Middle English {it}roc{/it}, from Middle Dutch {it}rocke{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}rocko{/it} distaff
shortdef: the wool or flax on a distaff

dt: {bc}a short tumbler {dx_def}see {dxt|tumbler:2||}{/dx_def} used especially for a {d_link|cocktail|cocktail:1} that is served over ice

dt.t: Combine all the ingredients in a shaker, shake vigorously. Strain and serve on the rocks—in a {wi}rocks glass{/wi} …

shortdef: a short tumbler used especially for a cocktail that is served over ice

shortdef: isolated rocky islets in the Atlantic Ocean 600 miles (966 kilometers) northeast of Natal, Brazil, that belong to Brazil

dt.t: He {it}gets his rocks off{/it} bossing everyone around.

shortdef: to feel great pleasure or satisfaction
